ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained significant insight into both the practical knowledge required to implement a mechatronic system, as well as the fundamental truths and theory behind the maths that control them.  We learned microprocessor architecture (and assembly), frequency domain analysis, and control theory.  This class had some of the most beautiful insights into mathematics I've ever had the pleasure of learning.
Block diagrams, laplace transforms, assembly programming language, understanding code and machines.
Troubleshooting, controller design, modeling systems
I learned about control systems, how to appropriately characterize and select motors, how to code microcontrollers
Learned about mechatronic systems and how they work.

I learned mechanics, control, and a great deal about computers. I improved my knowledge of electronics and mechanical systems. This course taught me how to dream up a robotic system and step by step build it and control it.
PID controllers.

I learned a lot of skills of how to develop mechatronic controllers and particularly vocabulary that will be useful when trying to approach this in the future. While I feel like a lot of the information was overwhelming, I also liked how much of the course was just about exposing us to ideas and procedures that would make it more accessible for us to navigate and teach ourselves on future projects that may not be identical to this one.
Microcontroller programming, robotics, control systems design and analysis, motors and actuators
Control systems, how to understand them, and how to design them.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:
Comprehensive course material.  Solid instruction.  Great teaching team.

Weaknesses:
Mediocre lab selection.  Lectures became extremely hard to follow toward the end.

Improvements:
Perhaps doing only one lab based on the IR sensor.  Also please be much more specific in the lab instructions exactly what data we would need for our lab reports.  I had to redo two labs to get data.  It wasn't fun.
The content is very interesting and important, but the labs in the virtual setting were often chaotic because of things going wrong often, and debugging hardware took up a lot of time.

I think Professor Venkadesan is very engaging and the course, on the surface, had very interesting material; however, I thought the organization of the course (especially the relationship between the lab and lecture portions) was lacking.

Strengths - this is a hands-on class, which is cool in theory but in covid is impossible to execute well. Also super great professor who makes lectures engaging and was really good with technology use

Weaknesses - this class honestly could not be done well with a pandemic. It is a class that has to be held in person

This course is very knowledge heavy. While all the information is relevant to success in the class, it's a lot to pack into 1 semester. It might do well to either cut away some of the material covered in this course, or split it into 2 separate semesters.

I loved the TA's.  Everyone's learning style is different and I personally benefitted from asking the TA's questions in addition to reading lecture notes.  I would say that any weaknesses from one style of teaching are compensated for by the additional styles that professor Venkadesan employs.

I felt like some of the lectures where overwhelming, and that the big ideas got lost in some of the smaller details. But the teaching staff was always great at meeting and helping us through content that we struggled with.

Well designed course with interesting material from the get-go, and topics that are strongly relevant to mechanical engineering and design. Could have been given a little more guidance about the Robot Grand Prix earlier, but understandable given covid uncertainties.
Weakness: the course needed a more clear structure so that students could understand the connections between every topic. Strengths: Lectures themselves were clear and interesting.

I felt that it went too deep into theory and barely into practice. I feel like it turned into a math class instead of teaching me how to efficiently use a microcontroller. I would like it if they did guided code walkthroughs and taught us about various things you can do with the microcontrollers. Also, the virtual labs felt like treading water for 3 hours, with unclear instructions that constantly contradicted themselves. More careful planning of labs would be greatly appreciated.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were fine, but as mentioned before the not-in-person labs were often terrible and mired in debugging things going wrong.

I think COVID-19 affected this class heavily. In all honesty, I strongly disliked the lab portion of this class. Almost all of the parts were faulty, the guidance (despite the diligent work of the TFs) was not enough to ensure that we were doing the lab procedures correctly. I spent more time debugging than actually working on the lab procedures and reports. Also, as a nitpick, there was a big disconnect between the lab procedures and the deliverables at times, sometimes leading me to do hours of work in accordance with the lab procedure with no deliverable to show for it.

I honestly think virtual lab was awful. The TAs did their best but two people troubleshooting individual code and hardware for 20 people was just not realistic. There is nothing that can really be done about this, but I would advise waiting to take this class if it is not going to be in person.

The teaching staff made sure to provide all the students with the materials necessary to take the class and complete the labs, efficiently restructuring labs and lectures to function better virtually, and made sure to provide help when necessary.
Khoi and Ali did an amazing job running virtual labs. Walking students through the lab at the start GREATLY helped to understand the material, minimize difficulties during lab, and enable our work.
Kits provided were well planned out and useful in learning. Some technical difficulties with the components chosen that led to extensive delays in labs and aassignments
Lecture recordings were definitely necessary for learning in this course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone in MechE or CS.  If you've learned a lot of math at Yale but been disappointed by how little you got to use it, take this course.  It not only shows you their practicalities, but the beautiful truth behind them.
Yeah, lots of interesting things, you get to play with circuitry and a cool robot.
If the class were virtual, no. If the class were in person, sure.

I would defnitely recommend this course to other students. There was a major damper on the class because of the virtual format, and even though I enjoyed the class, I could see how this class would have been so much better in person.

I personally did not love this class. It was well done, I just personally do not like and am not great at programming microcontrollers. If you are ABET MechE, you have to take it, and even if you are not ABET/have an interest in robotics it is really useful and is taught well. I personally just didn't like the content that much. If you like robotics, control systems, and want to get good at working with microcontrollers then you definitely should take it. It is a really hard class though and be prepared to deal with some weird code.

Yes. While it is a very difficult course, I feel that I actually learned useful information regarding the operation of mechatronic systems and tangibly applied them during the final project. It's also super rewarding to see how some of the previously covered material from other classes contributes to the overall field of mechanical engineering through this class.

Yes, absolutely! Not only is the material interesting, but this is also one of the few classes in the MechE curriculum that centers practical application of every theoretical thing you touch. Beyond that, the teaching team are INCREDIBLE. They all handled my issues, questions, and mental health struggles with compassion and grace. This class was difficult but it was never because the teaching team made it so. I can not express enough how much love I have for all of them.
Yes!  Interesting material presented compassionately with the problems forcing one to think.  I could not think of a more quintessentially Yale course.
Yes, one of the best classes in MENG major in my opinion in regards to the amount of applicable information you learn from it.
I would recommend if you are interested in robotics or mechatronic systems, as I feel that I gained a foundation from which to grow my own learning.

This is the best required course in the Mechanical Engineering major, and probably one of the best in the major overall. If it's taught by Prof. Venkadesan, don't hesitate to take it. If you're considering taking it as an elective, i highly recommend it. You will learn actual useful skills in mechatronics and practicalities of design and analysis. It's also a great introduction to robotics, which is an otherwise lacking field at Yale in MechE.
I would recommend this to another student who is interested in control systems, not afraid of math, and prepared to put in the work.
No. I would only recommend if it is a requirement of the major. It is not worth it. I felt like I would have learned more useful in an online Udemy course, with less work and less stress.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: End of term final project/ robot race
It was a combination of in-person labs, virtual labs and one in-person lab.
Virtual Lecture / Virtual Lab / In-Person Final Project Presentation (masked and conducted in small groups in the CEID)
Live virtual lecture and live virtual lab
Live virtual lecture and lab.
Live virtual labs
2 weekly zoom lectures + almost weekly virtual lab session
Live virtual lecture
Live virtual lecture with a live virtual lab approx every other week, for which materials were provided.
Live virtual lecture and recordings.
There were also live virtual lectures, which were recorded.
